results.headline: Review: In ‘Kill Your Friends,’ Corporate Climbing Can Prove Deadly
results.summary_short: The Britpop scene of the ‘90s takes it squarely on the chin in this blisteringly bleak yet richly satisfying poison-pen letter to the music industry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kill Your Friends

results.headline: Review: ‘Catching the Sun’ Profiles Solar Energy Entrepreneurs and Activists
results.summary_short: This documentary spotlights international efforts to build a green economy through solar power.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Catching the Sun

results.headline: Review: ‘No Home Movie,’ of Love and Melancholy
results.summary_short: Chantal Akerman’s last feature, about her mother, makes the viewer wonder how any of us, in our unguarded intimacy, manage to survive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Home Movie

results.headline: Review: ‘Notfilm’ Tells How Beckett and Keaton Collaborated
results.summary_short: This documentary about the making of the 1965 short movie “Film” features interviews and anecdotes about the two men.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Notfilm

results.headline: Review: ‘Francofonia,’ About World War II Foes Turned Allies, for the Sake of Art
results.summary_short: Alexander Sokurov’s unsettling film examines efforts by the Louvre’s director and a Nazi conservator to protect the Louvre’s collection.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Francofonia

results.headline: Review: ‘The Flight Fantastic’ Takes to the Air With the Flying Gaonas
results.summary_short: This documentary, by Tom Moore, explores the career of Tito Gaona and his three siblings, Mexican trapeze artists who brought a new verve to the form.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Flight Fantastic

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Girl in the Photographs,’ Ambitious Goals Slashed
results.summary_short: This horror film, with Wes Craven credited as executive producer, has a hackneyed sleaziness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl in the Photographs

results.headline: Review: In ‘Marinoni,’ a Racing Champion Turned Bicycle Craftsman
results.summary_short: This documentary follows Giuseppe Marinoni, 75, as he travels from his adopted home in Canada to Italy to compete for a speed record in his age group.
results.display_title: Marinoni: The Fire in the Frame

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marinoni: The Fire in the Frame

results.headline: Review: ‘Darling,’ a Horror Outing
results.summary_short: A young woman accepts an assignment from a wealthy matron to mind an upscale Manhattan apartment, only to unravel, in Mickey Keating’s film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Darling

results.headline: Review: In ‘H.,’ a Fireball Sends Things Spinning Out of Control
results.summary_short: This mysterious film, inspired by a Greek tragedy, depicts the parallel lives of two women named Helen in Troy, N.Y.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of H.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Everybody Wants Some!!,’ Casual Sex and Casual Philosophizing
results.summary_short: Richard Linklater calls his latest film, set in 1980, a “spiritual sequel” to “Dazed and Confused,” his 1970s high school masterpiece.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everybody Wants Some!!

results.headline: Review: ‘Sex and Broadcasting,’ With the Emphasis on the Latter
results.summary_short: The story of WFMU, a listener-supported radio station kept alive in the era of corporate financing by sometimes wacky labors of love.
results.display_title: Sex and Broadcasting — A Film About WFMU

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex and Broadcasting — A Film About WFMU

results.headline: Review: ‘I Don’t Belong Anywhere’ Explores the Life and Work of Chantal Akerman
results.summary_short: Marianne Lambert, who directed this documentary, was a production manager for Ms. Akerman, the groundbreaking Belgian director, who died in October.
results.display_title: I Don’t Belong Anywhere: The Cinema of Chantal Akerman

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Don’t Belong Anywhere: The Cinema of Chantal Akerman

results.headline: Review: ‘April and the Extraordinary World,’ Animated Sci-Fi From France
results.summary_short: In an altered century with stunted technology, a Parisian and her talking cat try to figure out why so many scientists are disappearing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of April and the Extraordinary World

results.headline: Review: ‘Fastball,’ on the Mechanics and Poetry of a Pitch
results.summary_short: This documentary, written and directed by Jonathan Hock, offers a batter’s point of view on trying to hit a superior fastball.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fastball

results.headline: Review: ‘Born to Be Blue,’ Portrait of a Trumpeter as a Heroin Addict
results.summary_short: Ethan Hawke plays Chet Baker in this extended riff on a jazz life written and directed by Robert Budreau.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Born to Be Blue

results.headline: Review: ‘I Saw the Light,’ a Hank Williams Biopic
results.summary_short: The British actor Tom Hiddleston stars (and sings) as the music legend, leading with charm and a twang in this film written and directed by Marc Abraham.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Saw the Light

results.headline: Review: In ‘Valley of Love,’ Isabelle Huppert and Gérard Depardieu as Mourning Parents
results.summary_short: The film, set in an otherworldly Death Valley landscape, depicts a once-married couple reflecting on a son who committed suicide.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Valley of Love

results.headline: Review: ‘Baskin,’ From Turkey, Blends Style and Gore
results.summary_short: This horror story, directed by Can Evrenol, focuses on a police officer who’s called to an ominous mansion.

results.headline: Review: ‘They’re Watching,’ and Reality TV Is Capturing Every Eerie Second
results.summary_short: This found-footage horror film from Micah Wright and Jay Lender separates itself from much of the genre’s low-budget fare with its amusing premise.
